Now, the reason that we don't often talk about NAS is that the margin is that it actually is spread right across the opps area and we actually leverage a lot of our existing capability so it becomes an allocation there, but over the next 12 months, 18 months we'll give you more and more clarity as we just sort of really focus in on that business and remember it is about how you put the services and the carriage together to deliver the service to the customer when you at the margin across both.

So that's the critical nature that we think we got opportunity, good opportunity and the plan is to improve our margin year-to-year as we go forward as we bring on these contracts, drive very strong what we call delivery towers, driving efficiency and data solutioning at the front end of the business, but we can pick that up with you separately. It is a – we've come a long way in that business which is good.

David, maybe to add as well looking at Paul Geason here, without sort of outing Paul under too much pressure. I mean, I think the other point to make is that as we sit here today, the proportion of sort of outlook and target for 2013 that is incumbent in existing contracts, which have been signed, because of those big contracts have been signed is a bigger proportion than it was this time last year, which I think all goes well for next year.
We have just three more questions from the phones.
Brad Clibborn from Credit Suisse. Please go ahead.

Good morning gents, thanks for your time. Just two quick ones from me, firstly in terms of the tax rate, effective tax rate is up to 30.6% from 28.6% the prior-year. Was there any tax impact from the TelstraClear sale and just what's driving that and where you are at from a franking perspective as well and just following on the point around NAS. Those contract wins and the ongoing growth in NAS, do you expect to see any pull through in terms of the data and IP side of the business. Thank you.

On the tax one, so no there is no real impact from the sale of TelstraClear. Our franking position is currently negative, $54 million you can see that from the statutory accounts. We do have as you'll see from the balance sheet, a number of tax, sort of adjustments to be lodged which is already just about making sure we've got the right franking situation. So there is nothing – there is no sort of systemic change in our tax position. It's just about making sure that the franking right, it's a negative $54 million balance, our outlook is that we're in a position to fully franc the dividend for 2013.

Yeah, and on the NAS question, yes, you do see pull through on the IP core access products, so we'll see good growth in that area as we go forward. That's the whole value proposition of that business as you pull through good next-generation carries to revenues.
Operator, we'll take the last question please.
Last question is from Paul Brunker, JPMorgan. Please go ahead.

Morning all. Just on mobile margins, there was some degree of slowdown in the second half as you said albeit from a high base. Has that somewhat helped margins through lower subscriber acquisition costs and would you expect FACs (1:35:04) to be rising in FY 2013 on the iPhone 5 and so I will just sneak another one on CapEx, your guidance I think referred to the accrued number, that's about $350 million less than the cash CapEx this year. If you can just clarify why that is – are we right to assume that that gap reverses next year?

All right. In terms of your first question on the mobiles, no, it's not significantly attributable the increase in margin. We are managing it better I think and therefore what, subsequently what phones, at what time, when we do it, re-contract rates, all those things are really important, but it's not significant in terms of the margin, I think it's been just a strong performance across a number of areas. In terms of going forward with the iPhone 5, look we do expect a slight increase, but over the full year I think we can manage it pretty well. It's still early days on that.

We need to get all the details, but we – as I said we don't intend to take a step backwards through this process and I think we've had good experience with the introduction of new phones from Apple now and there is no question good demand and whether there is demand that's good business. So, Gordon, do you want to comment anything more.

The only thing I'd say is one of the great shifts we've achieved this financial year is the quality of the mix of customers we are bringing on board, given the quality of the network and the introduction of LTE where we see if you looked a year ago, we would have had for price plans below $59, we would have had but in FY 2011, we were about 34 – sorry we would have had 34% of our customers above the $59 price point and above.

If you look at FY 2012, we are now about 71%. So what we see is an improvement in quality of customer, what we see is improvement in the quality of the mix, and the plan mix, we're seeking an improvement in the sage and customers wanting more inclusions because they are using data more and we are beginning to monetize that and that actually is reaping greater margin improvement and we don't see that abating. So that's why the margin improvement is sustainable notwithstanding as we shift to a year of re-contracting with the launch of iPhone 5. So that's a positive trend that we want to..
Thanks, Gordon. And any further questions?
Yeah, I might just give Mark Hall to answer the question.

Thanks Andy. On CapEx, I mentioned at the half that in the past we've had a program that ramps up during the course of the year. So obviously the cash impact of that spills over into the following year. What we've had this year is a program managed on a far more flatter basis i.e. even keel across the year. So we don't have that same impact. We would expect that to continue going forward.
Thanks, Mark. I think that's all the questions done today. I'll just hand it to David for any closing words. Then we'll close. Thank you.

Yeah thanks, Ben. I don't have a whole lot to say. Look, it's been a strong year's results. We're looking forward to this year, this full year 2013. I think we've got good momentum. We are across all the key things and thankfully there is still great demand for our products and services which makes it fun to be in this business. So thanks for your time and we look forward to talking to you over the next few weeks. Thank you.
